questions.text: Which of these following statements is true regarding the management of breast disorders? Nipple retraction always indicates an underlying malignancy. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of lactational mastitis. Fibroadenomas should always be offered excision, as they are associated with a high risk of malignancy. The histology of phyllodes tumour may be benign, intermediate or malignant. Select the correct answer from the given below code:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B, D Statement: B is true: Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of lactational infections. Fifty percent of infants harbour staphylococci in the nasopharynx. A cracked nipple might initiate mastitis and blocked lactiferous ducts with stagnant milk will allow organisms to multiply, leading to breast abscess. Early recognition and treatment with antibiotics, such as flucloxacillin or comoxiclav , can prevent abscess formation. Once the abscess is formed, the pus should be aspirated under ultrasound guidance. Some patients will require a mini- incision and drainage. MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus) infections can sometimes occur, particularly if the infection is hospital-acquired. Statement: D is true: Phyllodes tumours are usually single, unilateral, painless palpable breast masses. On clinical examination, the phyllodes tumours feel firm and well-circumscribed like fibroadenoma and might be slightly larger when first detected. It is impossible to differentiate smaller phyllodes tumours from fibroadenomas Features that alert a clinician to a phyllodes tumour include the following: Older age of the patient Larger tumour size History of rapid growth Phyllodes tumo u r is classified as benign, intermediate and The degree of stromal cellular atypia, mitotic activity per 10 high-power fields, presence or absence of stromal overgrowth (defined as a single 40 times field of pure stroma devoid of epithelium), infiltrative or expansile margins are the criteria used to subclassify phyllodes as benign, borderline, or malignant .

Highyeild:

Phyllodes tumour is a rare (< 1% of all breast tumours), large(>3cm), rapidly growing, discrete and firm painless breast lump. They are usually benign, but most of them have malignant potential. They originate from the hormonally responsive stromal cells of the breast. Clinical features Large breast with an unevenly bosselated surface. Pressure necrosis may cause skin ulceration. They are mobile on the chest wall Mostly seen in 40–50 years (premenopausal) age. Phyllodes tumours are fibroepithelial tumours composed of epithelial and stromal components. Biopsy shows a leaf-like appearance under the microscope.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Statement: A is false: Nipple retraction might be noticed during puberty when the breasts develop and the aetiology is unknown. This might cause difficulty in breastfeeding due to retained secretions. Recent retraction of nipple, particularly in older women, might be of considerable pathological significance. A slit-like retraction might be caused by duct ectasia and chronic periductal mastitis, whereas a circumferential nipple retraction is likely to be due to a malignancy. Statement: C is false : Fibroadenomas are not associated with a high risk of malignancy. They are offered excision if they are large or have suspicious cytology or when a patient desires to have them removed.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is true regarding the management of breast disorders?

options.label: A
options.text: Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) increases the risk of breast cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: Inflammatory breast cancer is caused by an infection in the breast.

options.label: C
options.text: Medullary carcinoma in the breast is associated with a poor prognosis.

options.label: D
options.text: Oestrogen receptor-negative tumours are treated with tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors.

questions.correct_answer: A. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) increases the risk of breast cancer.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) increases the risk of breast cancer. Statement A is true: Long-term use of combined preparation of HRT does significantly increase the risk of developing breast cancer. The effect is substantially greater for oestrogen and progesterone combinations than for other types of HRT.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B is false: Inflammatory breast cancer is not related to infection. It is a rare, aggressive type of breast cancer , presenting with swelling, redness, warmth and pain in the breast with oedema . It mimics cellulitis or abscess, but the findings are due to blocked subdermal lymphatics with tumour cells. The presence of cancer cells in the subdermal lymphatics confirms the diagnosis of inflammatory breast cancer. They used to be rapidly fatal, but with recent advances in systemic therapy, the prognosis has improved considerably. Option: C is false: Medullary carcinomas are rare breast cancers that have characteristic histopathological findings that show solid sheets of large cells with lymphoplasmacytic infiltration. They are often oestrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) negative. Medullary cancers, despite having an aggressive histological picture and being triple negative, often have a better prognosis than infiltrating duct carcinoma not of an otherwise specified type. Option: D is false: Women with ER-negative breast cancers should not be offered hormone manipulation. Oestrogen receptor expression is the main indicator of potential response to endocrine therapy. Approximately 70% of breast cancers are ER-positive and therefore hormone dependent. Premenopausal ER patients are treated with tamoxifen, which competes with oestrogen to block the oestrogen receptor selectively.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of breast disorders?

options.label: A
options.text: Adjuvant chemotherapy is not given to postmenopausal women with ER-positive breast cancer.

options.label: B
options.text: Tamoxifen reduces the risk of contralateral breast cancer.

options.label: C
options.text: Cyclophosphamide chemotherapy is as effective as anthracycline- and taxane-based chemotherapy.

options.label: D
options.text: Neoadjuvant chemotherapy improves breast conservation rates in women with slightly larger primary tumours (This option is also true)

questions.correct_answer: B. Tamoxifen reduces the risk of contralateral breast cancer.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Tamoxifen reduces the risk of contralateral breast cancer. Tamoxifen has been used widely in the hormonal management of breast cancer for more than four decades. Along with its intended benefit to reduce the recurrence rate and death from breast cancer, it also significantly reduces the risk of contralateral breast cancer.

Highyeild:

Hormonal therapy Hormonal therap y is an important treatment option for patients with hormone receptor-positive breast cancer. There are several types of hormonal therapy available, including: Ovarian suppression or ablation : This can be achieved through surgical removal of the ovaries (bilateral oophorectomy) or by using medications such as LHRH agonists (Goserelin, Leuprorelin) to suppress ovarian function. Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs): Tamoxifen and raloxifene are examples of SERMs that block the effects of estrogen in breast tissue. Aromatase inhibitors: Non-steroidal aromatase inhibitors, such as letrozole and anastrozole , and steroidal aromatase inhibitor exemestane , are used to block the production of estrogen. Anti-estrogens: Fulvestrant is an example of an anti-estrogen drug that binds to estrogen receptors and causes their degradation. Progestins: Megestrol and Medroxyprogesterone acetate are progestin drugs that can be used in combination with other hormonal therapies to increase their effectiveness.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Adjuvant chemotherapy is increasingly being offered to high-risk post-menopausal women. Gene signatures are increasingly used to tailor systemic therapy based on the recurrence scores. Option: C. The results of various studies comparing CMF versus anthracycline-containing regimens suggest a modest advantage for anthracycline regimens. The inclusion of taxanes further improves disease-free survival and overall survival. Hence, CMF is no longer considered adequate for adjuvant therapy. Option: D. Neoadjuvant chemotherapy was initially used to downsize locally advanced tumours to facilitate surgery. It was then used in operable breast cancer to decrease the tumour size to facilitate breast conservation. However, neoadjuvant chemotherapy has no additional advantage over disease-free survival or overall survival when compared with standard adjuvant therapy.

options.label: A
options.text: Lymphoedema in the arm after treatment usually indicates a recurrence.

options.label: B
options.text: Radiotherapy after implant reconstruction of the breast gives poor cosmetic results.

options.label: C
options.text: Chemotherapy is safe in the second and third trimesters in women with pregnancy-associated breast cancer.

options.label: D

questions.correct_answer: A. Lymphoedema in the arm after treatment usually indicates a recurrence.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lymphoedema in the arm after treatment usually indicates a recurrence. Lymphoedema of the arm is a troublesome complication of breast cancer treatment that can occur anytime from months to years after treatment. The incidence of lymphoedema is significantly higher when axillary dissection is combined with axillary radiation. It is less seen now as axillary dissection and radiotherapy to the axilla are rarely combined. Besides, sentinel lymph node biopsy has been widely adopted as the standard of care in clinically node-negative axilla.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. Radiotherapy after implant-based reconstructions can lead to fibrosis and capsular contracture surrounding the implant, resulting in unacceptable results. Implant-based reconstruction after the chest wall has been treated with radiotherapy is also associated with several problems. Delayed or poor wound healing can occur due to the effects of radiotherapy. Autologous reconstructions are a better option if radiotherapy to the chest wall is anticipated. Option: C. Chemotherapy should be avoided in the first trimester, but it appears to be safe in the second and third trimesters. Therefore, chemotherapy might be administered as neoadjuvant or adjuvant therapy in the second or third trimester. Option: D. Stage for determining, the treatment and prognosis of male breast cancer is similar to female breast cancer. Male breast cancer accounts for <1% of all breast cancers.

questions.text: 26-year-old breast-feeding mother presents as an emergency with pain, swelling in the right breast and fever for 2 days. Diagnosis:

options.label: A
options.text: ANDI (Aberration of normal development and involution)

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breast abscess Breast abscess: Lactation-associated infections are the most common infections in the breast. It occurs normally within 6 to 8 weeks following delivery. Patients often present with pain, swelling and redness along with fever and chills. There might be a tender, palpable lump with stretched, discoloured, shiny skin. The abscess starts to point, and with skin necrosis, the pus is discharged. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism.

Highyeild:

Breast abscess Breast abscesses are commonly caused by staphylococcal infections . They are characterised by symptoms such as tenderness at a specific point, redness, and fever. These abscesses are often related to lactation and can occur during the first few weeks of breastfeeding. The transmission of S. aureus occurs through the neonate's suckling.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. ANDI: There is sound clinical evidence that many benign breast conditions, especially cyclical pain, nodularity and cysts are likely to have their pathogenesis in hormonal events during reproductive life. ANDI is a term used to describe the most benign breast diseases. It is based on the fact that most benign breast disorders are relatively minor aberrations of the normal processes of development, cyclical hormonal response and involution. Patients may give a history of cyclical mastalgia and nodularity. Persistent dominant nodules that are palpable clinically might require imaging evaluation and histopathological correlation. Option: B. Phyllodes tumour: Phyllodes should certainly be considered as a possibility in an older woman presenting with a rapidly enlarging breast mass. The rapidity of growth by itself does not indicate malignant potential. Because of the rapidity of growth, the mass may produce visible bulging when it expands quickly, with shiny and stretched skin with dilated veins over the mass as it pushes against the skin. The skin may ulcerate secondary to ischemia due to pressure on the overlying skin. Option: D. Breast cyst: Symptomatic cysts present with a palpable breast mass or masses that might develop suddenly and be associated with pain and tenderness. Clinically detected breast mass cannot be characterised as a cyst on the basis of physical findings alone.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman attends the breast clinic with a strong family history of breast cancer. Two of her sisters, her mother and her maternal aunt’s daughter had breast cancer at an early age. She wants to know her risk of getting breast cancer. What will you advise her?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

BRCA1 & 2 testing BRCA1 and 2 tests: Women who are thought to be gene carriers may be offered BRCA 1 and BRCA 2 BRCA 1 gene is located in the long arm of chromosome 17 and BRCA2 in the short arm of chromosome 13. Genetic counselling should be offered before testing. Those who test positive have a 50%–80% risk of developing breast cancer and a 15%–45% risk of developing ovarian cancer in their lifetime.

Indications for genetic risk evaluation in breast cancer:- Family history of breast cancer diagnosed before the age of 50 TNBC diagnosed before the age of 60 Male breast cancer, Two or more breast cancer primaries, and the presence of specific cancers or multiple affected relatives. Family history of certain cancers, such as colon or endometrial cancer, thyroid cancer, etc.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman feels a hard lump that is painless and gradually increasing in size over the past 4 months. Her mammogram shows a spiculated mass in the right breast. Diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Carcinoma Spiculated lesions on a mammogram are very suspicious of a malignancy. She requires a core needle biopsy of the lesion. Core needle biopsy allows a definitive diagnosis, with the possibility of differentiation between in situ and invasive disease. It is also possible to obtain oestrogen and progesterone receptors and HER2 receptor status for treatment planning. It is particularly important to do a core biopsy before neoadjuvant chemotherapy. Although fine-needle aspiration (FNAC) is quick, easy and much more cost-effective to do, it is associated with high false-negative results and inconclusive smears.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman presented with a greenish-black nipple discharge on both sides. Diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duct ectasia Bilateral greenish-black discharge in a premenopausal woman is likely to be due to duct ectasia. Duct ectasia is usually due to the progressive involution of ducts With increasing age, the myoepithelial layer of the major ducts loses its elasticity and contractility resulting in progressive duct dilatation and thickening of its walls. The stagnant secretions within the blocked duct get thicker and inspissated.

Highyeild:

Duct ectasia is more common in smokers and its cause is unclear. The disorder begins with the dilatation in one or more lactiferous ducts , which can fill with a stagnant brown or green secretion that may discharge. Common symptoms include nipple discharge (of any colour ), subareolar mass , abscess , mammary duct fistula , and nipple retraction . Diagnosis is made through ductography , which can identify the dilated cystic structure in duct ectasia.

It has been shown to reduce the annual rate of recurrence by 25%, with a 17% reduction in the annual rate of death. Selective estrogen receptor modulators (SERMs): Tamoxifen and raloxifene are examples of SERMs that block the effects of estrogen in breast tissue. Aromatase inhibitors: Non-steroidal aromatase inhibitors, such as letrozole and anastrozole , and steroidal aromatase inhibitor exemestane , are used to block the production of estrogen. Anti-estrogens: Fulvestrant is an example of an anti-estrogen drug that binds to estrogen receptors and causes their degradation.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . SERMs are a type of anti-oestrogen therapy used to treat oestrogen receptor-positive breast cancers. Option: C. Raloxifene is a selective oestrogen receptor modulator with an oestrogen-agonistic effect on bone receptors and is used in the risk reduction of invasive breast cancer in postmenopausal women. Option: D . Tamoxifen is a selective ER modulator that has antagonistic and weak agonistic effects. Beneficial effects of tamoxifen include reducing the risk of tumours in the contralateral breast.

Extraedge:

Progestins: Megestrol and Medroxyprogesterone acetate are progestin drugs that can be used in combination with other hormonal therapies to increase their effectiveness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female was diagnosed with breast cancer (left side, with skin invasion). She was treated by lumpectomy, with no chemotherapy or radiotherapy. She refused further standard treatment after the operation. Which one of the following is the most common complication following a modified radical mastectomy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Seromas Seromas beneath the skin flaps or in the axilla represent the most frequent complication of mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection, reportedly occurring in as many as 30% of cases. The use of closed-system suction drainage reduces the incidence of this complication.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Wound infections occur infrequently after a mastectomy, and the majority are a result of skin-flap necrosis . Option: C. Moderate or severe haemorrhage in the postoperative period is rare and is best managed with early wound exploration for control of haemorrhage and re-establishment of closed-system suction drainage. Option: D. The incidence of functionally significant lymphedema after a modified radical mastectomy is approximately 20% but can be as high as 50% to 60% when postoperative radiation is employed.

questions.text: A 45- year- old female patient presents with a breast mass of size 3 cm in diameter with palpable ipsilateral two axillary lymph nodes and no evidence of distant metastases. What is the surgical management in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Modified radical mastectomy with sentinel lymph node dissection

options.label: B
options.text: Modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection

questions.correct_answer: B. Modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Modified radical mastectomy with axillary lymph node dissection Modified radical mastectomy (MRM) comprises a simple mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection is the preferred procedure for patients. A modified radical mastectomy with metastases to the axillary lymph nodes will remove the affected skin, a generalized disease process in the breast, and involved lymph nodes. This will contribute to improved local control of the disease process.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. A sentinel lymph node biopsy is not indicated since there is already known disease in the axillary nodes. Option: C. Hormonal therapy is better used as adjuvant therapy. Option: D. Palliative care plays a bigger role for those with metastatic breast cancer than for those with early breast cancer. Palliative care in metastatic breast cancer care is the management and prevention of symptoms and side effects related to cancer and/or its treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following breast cancer is an absolute contraindication for Sentinel node lymph biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

IBC Inflammatory breast cancer is an absolute contraindication for Sentinel node lymph biopsy. Sentinel lymph node biopsy is not performed for inflammatory breast cancer as ALND should always be performed. ALND remains the standard of care for patients with locally advanced breast cancer or inflammatory breast cancer, patients with a positive sentinel node who are scheduled for mastectomy, patients with a positive sentinel node who are scheduled for accelerated partial breast irradiation (APBI), and patients with clinically positive nodes as well as a positive sentinel node after neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. DCIS is not an absolute contraindication of Sentinalsentinel node lymph node biopsy. Option: B. LCIS is not an absolute contraindication of Sentinalsentinel node lymph node biopsy. Option: D. None of the above - is not a correct option.

questions.text: On Clinical examination of the breast of a 27- year- old female, a hard lump was found in the upper outer quadrant. Mammography revealed the presence of multiple lumps on the upper inner quadrant and lower inner quadrant, which was not palpable on Clinical examination. Biopsy reports revealed the suspicion of malignancy. What is the most preferred surgical management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patey’s mastectomy The modified radical (Patey’s) mastectomy is more commonly performed. Mastectomy is indicated for large tumours (in relation to the size of the breast), central tumours beneath or involving the nipple, multifocal disease, local recurrence or patient preference.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: The radical Halsted mastectomy, which included excision of the breast, axillary lymph nodes and pectoralis major and minor muscles, is no longer indicated as it causes excessive morbidity with no survival benefit. Option: Breast-Conserving Surgery has been referred to by many terms, including lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, segmental mastectomy, segmentectomy, tylectomy, and wide local excision. Option: D . Breast-Conserving Surgery has been referred to by many terms, including lumpectomy, partial mastectomy, segmental mastectomy, segmentectomy, tylectomy, and wide local excision.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female underwent a core-needle biopsy of a palpable 4 cm left breast mass in the upper outer quadrant that revealed invasive ductal carcinoma. On physical exam, she had no further palpable lesions and palpable axillary lymph nodes. Metastatic work-up was negative. Which of the following is not true about Patey’s mastectomy?

options.label: A
options.text: It is also called modified radical mastectomy

options.label: B
options.text: Intercostal brachial nerves are usually preserved

options.label: C
options.text: All lymph nodes of the axilla are removed

options.label: D
options.text: Pectoralis minor muscle is either divided or retracted

questions.correct_answer: B. Intercostal brachial nerves are usually preserved
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intercostal brachial nerves are usually preserved The intercostal brachial nerves are usually divided in this operation and the patient should be warned about sensation changes postoperatively. The axillary vein and nerves to the serratus anterior and latissimus dorsi (the thoracodorsal trunk) should be preserved.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . It is also called modified radical mastectomy. Option: C. The excised mass is composed of the whole breast, a large portion of skin, the centre of which overlies the tumour but which always includes the nipple and all of the fat, fascia and lymph nodes of the axilla Option: D. The pectoralis minor muscle is either divided or retracted to gain access to the upper two-thirds of the axilla.

questions.text: A 45- year- old female was diagnosed with Ductal Carcinoma of the Right breast with a mass of 3 cm on the upper outer quadrant with no lymph node involvement. Which of the following can be done for effective local control of Cancer?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mastectomy and SLND For patients with T1N0 or T2N0 breast cancer, mastectomy and SLND provide effective local control, and radiation therapy is not required. The modified radical (Patey’s) mastectomy is more commonly performed. The radical Halsted mastectomy, which included excision of the breast, axillary lymph nodes and pectoralis major and minor muscles, is no longer indicated as it causes excessive morbidity with no survival benefit.

Mastectomy is indicated for large tumours (in relation to the size of the breast), central tumours beneath or involving the nipple, multifocal disease, local recurrence or patient preference. Option: C. For patients with invasive breast cancer treated with breast-conserving surgery, adjuvant irradiation of the breast has been conclusively demonstrated to reduce the probability of breast recurrence and improve outcomes. Option: D. The use of neoadjuvant chemotherapy offers the opportunity to observe the response of the intact primary tumour and any regional nodal metastases to a specific chemotherapy regimen.

questions.text: A 32- year- old female presented with a palpable breast mass. Mammogram revealed a mass of 2 cm on the upper outer quadrant. Wide local excision of the tumour along with Sentinel Lymph node biopsy was planned. Which of the following agents provides the best result on SLND?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Radioisotope and Plain dye Using the combination technique may result in the lowest possible false-negative rate. Hence a combination of Radioisotope and Plain dye provides the best result.

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Radioisotope can be used alone but doesn’t provide the best result. Option: B . Plain dye can be used alone but doesn’t provide the best result. Option: None of the above - is not a correct option.

questions.text: A 37- year- old presented with complaints of cough, back pain and severe swelling of the right arm, and her pathological findings were invasive ductal carcinoma, N0 (no nodes were involved), negative surgical margin, grade 3, ER+, PR+, HER2+. Chest positron emission tomography and computed tomography (PET CT) showed a right axillary tumour, spinal metastases, intrapleural nodular tumour and right pleural effusion. Which one of the following is not an adjuvant therapy in the management of breast carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Breast-conservative therapy Breast conservation involves resection of the primary breast cancer with a margin of normal-appearing breast tissue, adjuvant radiation therapy, and assessment of regional lymph node status . Surgery still has a central role to play in the management of breast cancer but there has been a gradual shift towards more conservative techniques. Conservative breast cancer surgery is aimed at removing the tumour plus a margin of normal breast tissue .

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A . Systemic therapy targeted at putative micro-metastases is expected to delay relapse and prolong survival and is used as adjuvant therapy. Option: C . It is conventional to combine conservative surgery with radiotherapy to the remaining breast tissue. Recurrence rates are too high for treatment by local excision alone except in special cases (small node-negative tumours of a special type). Option: D . Chemotherapy using a first-generation regime such as a 6-monthly cycle of cyclophosphamide, methotrexate and 5-fluorouracil (CMF) will achieve a 25% reduction in the risk of relapse over a 10–15-year period and is used as an adjuvant therapy.
